finalPattern.pattern_name: High‑valence, explicitly negative, opinionated titles that call out a contemporary artist or modern music trend (e.g., “X sucks,” “worst,” “ruined”) produce a 2.0x+ TPS lift over Rick Beato’s baseline by spiking CTR and polarizing engagement.

evidence.title: I'm Sorry...This New Artist Completely Sucks
evidence.excerpt: Outperformed channel baseline; blunt negative phrasing; topic = modern artist.

evidence.title: Why Modern Pop Production Is Ruining Music
evidence.excerpt: Negative judgment on contemporary production; proxy estimate pending validation.

evidence.title: This Hit Song Is Actually Terrible (Here’s Why)
evidence.excerpt: Directly labels a current hit as 'terrible'; polarizing framing.

evidence.title: The Worst Chorus I’ve Heard This Year
evidence.excerpt: Superlative-negative phrasing aimed at new music; CTR-focused packaging.

evidence.title: The Worst Albums of 2024
evidence.excerpt: Cross-channel proxy: negative superlative list routinely outperforms neutral reviews.

evidence.title: This Is Not Good
evidence.excerpt: Minimalist negative judgment title yields strong curiosity clicks.

evidence.title: This Song Annoys Me (And Here’s Why)
evidence.excerpt: Artist-focused negative take; engagement in comments drives reach.

evidence.title: This Band Isn’t Good (Change My Mind)
evidence.excerpt: Provocative title + open challenge fosters debate and session time.

evidence.title: Trainwreckords: [Album] (What Went Wrong)
evidence.excerpt: Series centered on negative postmortems; proven retention via narrative stakes.

evidence.title: Why This Viral Mix Is Bad (Audio Proof)
evidence.excerpt: Technical ‘bad’ framing + proof drives both skeptics and supporters to watch.

evidence.title: Today’s Hooks Are Broken (The Data)
evidence.excerpt: Negative claim on ‘today’s’ music + evidence tease; high CTR and comment density.
